item.title: A Local AI Art Creation Tool | Remote Tech Steward Startup Weekly (15)
item.description: This week I participated in developing Jaaz, an open-source AI art tool. Discussing the commercialization challenges of open-source projects. Analyzing how information overload leads to decision paralysis, affecting content creation and direction choices. Sharing thoughts and confusion during the programmer’s freelancing entrepreneurship journey, and how to balance personal development with busy work.

item.title: Don't Rely on a Single Platform or Single Income Source | Remote Tech Steward Startup Weekly (14)
item.description: As a remote tech steward, I’ve realized the importance of building multi-platform exposure and diversified income streams. A personal website serves as a home base free from platform restrictions, while existing clients are valuable business resources. In the uncertain entrepreneurial journey, proactively expanding business, maintaining client relationships, and diversifying income sources are the only ways to achieve true career security - just like farmers who don’t plant only one crop.

item.title: A Failed Second Development Experience | Remote IT Concierge Startup Weekly (13)
item.description: A cross-platform desktop application development experience where binary search successfully located and fixed a MacOS compatibility bug; and a failed second development experience, revealing the enormous challenges of refactoring messy code projects, along with valuable lessons learned. The article emphasizes the importance of evaluating existing code quality and refactoring risks.

item.title: Entrepreneurs Have No Holidays | Remote IT Concierge Startup Weekly (12)
item.description: This week I reflect on my current startup status and explore the challenges in content creation and product direction. On the entrepreneurial journey, there are no holidays, but direction is more important than effort.

item.title: No More Tasks | Remote Tech Manager Startup Weekly (10)
item.description: This week I finally completed backlogged projects and had free time for personal development. As a remote tech manager, I developed a VSCode extension that formats Markdown content for WeChat Official Accounts with one click. This solves the hassle of switching between multiple applicationsâ€”from VSCode editing to third-party rendering to publishing on WeChat. While similar web applications exist, a VSCode plugin better fits developers’ workflow. The extension is expected to be released next week.

item.title: A Powerful Tool for English Output | Remote IT Concierge Startup Weekly (9)
item.description: This week, I developed inpot-desktop based on the open-source project Pot, focusing on translating Chinese to English. Traditional translation processes are cumbersome, with most tools focusing on translating foreign languages to native languages rather than vice versa. inpot-desktop optimizes user experience by solving pain points such as source text loss during window switching and slow translation window response, providing a convenient and efficient translation tool for international communication.

item.title: Remote IT Concierge Startup Weekly (7) - Order Explosion
item.description: This week was filled with orders ranging from technical consulting, AI programming education, to project internationalization, Docker deployment, and ECharts visualization. As a self-taught programmer, I’ve discovered that technical breadth is highly practical in the freelance market, offering limited income but greater freedom. I share insights on solving technical challenges, pricing strategies, and reflect on whether programmers should focus on technical depth or expand their breadth.

item.title: Remote IT Concierge Startup Weekly (8) - Having Work Keeps the Mind at Ease
item.description: As a remote tech butler, this week I established a half-day cooperation with an outsourcing company, achieving a win-win situation. Through this experience, I deeply understood the principle of “having work keeps the mind at ease,” which I break down into two key dimensions, “having skills” and “having clients.”

item.title: Remote IT Concierge Startup Weekly (6) - First Consulting Business
item.description: In the sixth week of my remote technical butler startup, I welcomed my first consulting business, exchanging thoughts on life and technical issues with a soon-to-graduate college student. This experience made me realize everyone can provide valuable consultation. This article shares my understanding of “margin of safety,” how to deal with career confusion, and thoughts on packaging consulting services into products.

item.title: Remote IT Concierge Startup Weekly (5) - Solving Big Problems with Small Investment
item.description: This week, I shifted from “self-rescue” to “entrepreneurship,” establishing my position as a Remote IT Concierge. Currently focusing on selective project acceptance while restarting my personal product development plan, steadily moving towards creating profitable products.

item.title: Weekly: 33-years-old Unemployed Programmer's Self-rescue(2) - Writing Academic Papers
item.description: A real experience of a 33-year-old unemployed programmer taking on his first machine learning paper project, documenting his 4-day journey from zero knowledge to delivery.

item.title: Weekly: 33-years-old Unemployed Programmer's Self-rescue (1)
item.description: A true self-rescue record of a 33-year-old unemployed programmer, from a Shenzhen programmer to a Lijiang hostel owner, and then to remote work. This article details how a middle-aged programmer seeks new career paths in rural areas through remote freelancing, content creation, and independent development. It’s a story about how tech professionals can save themselves, as well as a practical guide for career transition.
